title: You Have Learned HTML,Now What?

metadata.description: Learn about You Have Learned HTML,Now What? with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Introduction
content_sections.content:
You Have Learned HTML,
Now What?

content_sections.title: You Have Learned HTML
content_sections.content:
,
Now What?

HTML Summary
This tutorial has taught you how to use HTML to create your own web site.
HTML is the universal markup language for the Web. HTML lets you format text, add graphics, 
create links, input forms, frames and tables, etc., and save it all in a text file that any
browser can read and display.
For more information on HTML, please take a look at our
HTML examples
and our
HTML reference
.
You can also test your HTML skills with
HTML Exercises
and
HTML Quizzes
.
Now You Know HTML, What's 
Learn CSS
CSS lets you style your HTML pages.
CSS gives you total control of the layout, without messing up the document content.
To learn more about CSS, please visit our
CSS tutorial
.
Learn JavaScript
JavaScript makes your website more dynamic. A dynamic website can react to events and allow user interaction.
JavaScript is the most popular scripting language on the internet and it works with all major browsers.
If you want to learn more about JavaScript, please visit our
JavaScript tutorial
.
Publishing Your Website
To make your website available to the world, you must publish it.
For this, you have two options:
Use an Internet Service Provider
Host your own website
Using an Internet Service Provider
An Internet service provider (ISP) is a company that provides services for 
accessing and using the Internet.
Internet services typically provided by ISPs include Internet access, 
Internet transit, domain name registration, web hosting, Usenet service, and 
colocation.
Using an Internet Service Provider (ISP) is the most common option.
Advantages:

content_sections.title: Connection Speed
content_sections.content: - ISPs have very fast connections to the internet.

content_sections.title: Powerful Hardware
content_sections.content: - ISPs have powerful web servers that can be shared by several clients.

content_sections.title: Security and Stability
content_sections.content:
- ISPs are specialists on web hosting. Expect more than 99% up time, the latest software patches, and the best virus protection
Things to Consider:
24-hour support
- The ISP should offer 24-hours support. Toll-free phone could also be vital

content_sections.title: Daily Backup
content_sections.content: - The ISP must run a daily backup routine

content_sections.title: Traffic Volume
content_sections.content:
- Check the ISP's traffic volume restrictions (do not end up paying a fortune for unexpected
high traffic)

content_sections.title: Bandwidth or Content Restrictions
content_sections.content:
- Check the ISP's bandwidth and content restrictions (Is it possible to publish pictures, video, or sound?)
E-mail Capabilities
- Make sure the ISP supports the e-mail capabilities you need

content_sections.title: Database Access
content_sections.content:
- Make sure the ISP supports the database access you need
Hosting Your Own Website
Hosting your own website, on your own server, is also an option.
Things to Consider:

content_sections.title: Hardware Expenses
content_sections.content:
- To run a "real" web site, you must buy powerful 
server hardware (a low cost PC will not do the job). You will also 
need a permanent (24/7) high-speed connection

content_sections.title: Software Expenses
content_sections.content:
- Server-licenses are often higher than client-licenses.
 Server-licenses also might have limits on number of users

content_sections.title: Labor Expenses
content_sections.content:
- Don't expect low labor expenses. You have to install your own hardware and software.
You also have to deal with bugs and viruses, and keep your server constantly running

quiz.question: What is HTML?
options: the most popular scripting language on the internet and it works with all major browsers
the universal markup language for the Web
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of HTML is 'the universal markup language for the Web'.

quiz.question: What is JavaScript?
options: the most popular scripting language on the internet and it works with all major browsers
the universal markup language for the Web
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of JavaScript is 'the most popular scripting language on the internet and it works with all major browsers'.

summary: This tutorial covers You Have Learned HTML,Now What? concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use You Have Learned HTML,Now What? effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of You Have Learned HTML,Now What? and how to apply it in your projects.
